question: It has always been against the policy of despotic governments to suffer the victims of their persecutions to [MASK].
source_info: The Count of Monte Cristo, Illustrated by père, Alexandre Dumas
title: The Count of Monte Cristo, Illustrated
prev_sentence: Formerly they believed themselves sprung from Jupiter, and shielded by their birth; but nowadays they are not inviolable.
next_sentence: As the Inquisition rarely allowed its victims to be seen with their limbs distorted and their flesh lacerated by torture, so madness is always concealed in its cell, from whence, should it depart, it is conveyed to some gloomy hospital, where the doctor has no thought for man or mind in the mutilated being the jailer delivers to him.

question: Thus, the greater [MASK] of a manâs errors come before him disguised under the specious form of necessity; then, after error has been committed in a moment of excitement, of delirium, or of fear, we see that we might have avoided and escaped it.
source_info: The Count of Monte Cristo, Illustrated by père, Alexandre Dumas
title: The Count of Monte Cristo, Illustrated
prev_sentence: It is generally the case that what we most ardently desire is as ardently withheld from us by those who wish to obtain it, or from whom we attempt to snatch it.
next_sentence: The means we might have used, which we in our blindness could not see, then seem simple and easy, and we say, âWhy did I not do this, instead of that?â Women, on the contrary, are rarely tormented with remorse; for the decision does not come from you,âyour misfortunes are generally imposed upon you, and your faults the results of othersâ crimes.â  âIn any case, sir, you will allow,â replied Madame Danglars, âthat, even if the fault were alone mine, I last night received a severe punishment for it.â  âPoor thing,â said Villefort, pressing her hand, âit was too severe for your strength, for you were twice overwhelmed, and yetâââ  âWell?â  âWell, I must tell you.
